matched.expectedTitle: SQL Injection in GraphQL Jobs Query
matched.actualTitle: SQL Injection in GraphQL jobType Parameter
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the same core vulnerability: SQL injection through unsanitized jobType parameter in GraphQL queries. The actual findings provide comprehensive evidence of the vulnerability including boolean-based injection (OR '1'='1'), UNION SELECT exploitation, and access to restricted jobs (ID 3). This directly corresponds to the expected finding regarding direct SQL interpolation without parameterization at app/main.py line 67.

matched.location: GraphQL jobType parameter in /graphql/ endpoint - Restricted Job Access
matched.expectedTitle: SQL Injection in GraphQL Jobs Query
matched.actualTitle: SQL Injection in GraphQL jobType Parameter Exposes Restricted Jobs
matched.matchReason: This is a variant/more specific documentation of the same SQL injection vulnerability, focused on the access control bypass aspect. The expected finding mentions 'access to private jobs data' and this actual finding demonstrates exactly that with ID 3 'Internal Position' with type 'restricted' being exposed through injection.

extra.title: GraphQL Alias Amplification Attack - Query Multiplication DoS
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. This is a valid vulnerability where the GraphQL endpoint allows unrestricted field aliases (100+ aliases in a single query) causing query multiplication attacks. Confirmed with POC showing all 100 aliases processed successfully in 35ms with 1101 byte response. This represents a genuine DoS/resource exhaustion vulnerability independent of the SQL injection.

extra.title: GraphQL Introspection Enabled - Information Disclosure
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. The GraphQL endpoint allows unauthenticated introspection queries without authentication or authorization checks. Attackers can enumerate complete schema including all types, fields, arguments, and custom types (Query, Job, etc.). Valid security finding that significantly reduces reconnaissance time for attackers.

extra.title: Stored XSS in Job Data Display
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Valid vulnerability: Application displays job data (name, description, type) directly to innerHTML without HTML encoding or escaping. If any job record contains HTML or JavaScript code, it will execute when displayed. Confirmed with vulnerable code pattern analysis: resultDiv.innerHTML with unescaped template literals ${job.name}, ${job.description}, ${job.type}.

extra.title: Stored XSS via SQL Injection in Job Data
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. This is a chained vulnerability combining SQL injection with unsafe DOM manipulation. Attacker can inject malicious JavaScript through GraphQL jobType parameter via UNION SELECT, which gets returned and executed via innerHTML without sanitization. Represents a multi-vector attack pattern.

extra.title: Database Schema Disclosure via SQL Injection
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Valid vulnerability enabling extraction of complete database schema using sqlite_master table via UNION SELECT injection. Reveals CREATE TABLE statements, column definitions, data types, and primary key configuration. Facilitates more targeted SQL injection attacks through reconnaissance.

extra.title: Improper Input Validation - Client-Side GraphQL Query Injection
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Valid vulnerability: GraphQL queries are constructed on client-side using template literals with unescaped jobType parameter. Allows query structure manipulation and injection of additional GraphQL operations. Proper approach would use GraphQL variables for parameterization instead of string interpolation.

extra.title: GraphQL Query Filter Bypass - Empty String Argument
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Valid vulnerability: When jobType argument is empty string or omitted, the endpoint returns all jobs without applying any filter, bypassing intended access control mechanisms. Returns 3 jobs when filtering is completely bypassed versus 1-2 jobs when valid filters are applied.

extra.title: Reflected XSS in GraphQL Error Messages
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Valid vulnerability: GraphQL error messages are displayed via innerHTML without HTML encoding or escaping. While current server doesn't reflect user input in errors, the vulnerable code pattern exists and could be exploited if implementation changes. Defense-in-depth issue.

extra.title: GraphQL Endpoint Vulnerable to CSRF via GET Request Support
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Valid vulnerability: GraphQL endpoint accepts GET requests with query parameters, enabling Cross-Site Request Forgery attacks. Confirmed that GET requests with crafted queries execute successfully. Can be exploited via image tags, iframes, or redirects without user interaction.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection on GraphQL Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Valid vulnerability: GraphQL endpoint accepts POST requests without CSRF token validation. No X-CSRF-Token headers in responses, no token validation in requests. Creates vulnerability for state-changing operations if mutations are implemented. SameSite cookie attribute not set.

extra.title: Information Disclosure via SQL Error Messages
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Valid vulnerability: Detailed SQL error messages exposed to users revealing database table names, SQL syntax, column count information (e.g., 'no such table: users', 'SELECTs to the left and right of UNION do not have the same number of result columns'), and database software identification. Significantly assists SQL injection exploitation.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers on GraphQL Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Valid but lower severity: Missing X-Content-Type-Options, X-Frame-Options, X-XSS-Protection, Content-Security-Policy, and Strict-Transport-Security headers. While these are defense-in-depth measures and not directly exploitable, they reduce security posture. CSP could have mitigated XSS impact if configured.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers - XSS Protection and Content-Type Options
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Duplicate/related to previous security headers finding. Specifically focuses on X-XSS-Protection and X-Content-Type-Options headers missing from HTTP responses. Represented in multiple actual finding documents but represents same underlying issue.

extra.title: Database Software Version Disclosure via SQL Injection
extra.assessment: New discovery - Not in expected findings. Valid information disclosure vulnerability: SQLite version (3.40.1) can be extracted using sqlite_version() function via UNION SELECT injection. Enables identification of version-specific CVEs and planning of targeted database attacks. Demonstrates full extent of SQL injection capabilities.
